keyTakeAways: Sam Rivers, the bassist and founding member of Limp Bizkit, died at the age of 48.
Rivers' death was confirmed by Limp Bizkit, who described him as a 'pure magic' force behind their music and a 'true legend of legends'.
Rivers left the band in 2015 due to liver disease, which resulted from excessive drinking, and underwent a successful liver transplant in 2015–2016.
He rejoined the band in 2018 after recovery and continued to be involved in music until his death.
Rivers' last social media post was a 'Save The Date' video for a 2026 performance at the Rock for People festival in Hradec Králové, Czech Republic.
Limp Bizkit rose to fame in the 1990s, with hits like 'Rollin'' and 'Nookie' reaching the Billboard Hot 100 and receiving three Grammy nominations.
Fred Durst, the band’s frontman, recalls first hearing Rivers play at a Jacksonville bar and being instantly impressed by his bass playing and unique use of a five-string bass.
Limp Bizkit's new single 'Making Love to Morgan Wallen' topped several Billboard charts in September 2025, reflecting the band’s continued relevance and success.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sam Rivers, the founding bassist and a central figure in the nu-metal band Limp Bizkit, has died at the age of 48. The band confirmed his death and praised him as a 'pure magic' force behind their music, describing him as a 'true legend of legends' whose spirit lives on in every song and performance. Rivers left the band in 2015 due to severe liver disease caused by excessive drinking, underwent a successful liver transplant, and rejoined in 2018. His last public activity was a social media post in May 2025 promoting a 2026 performance at the Rock for People festival in Hradec Králové, Czech Republic. Limp Bizkit, which gained fame in the 1990s with hits like 'Rollin'' and 'Nookie' and three Grammy nominations, continues to thrive, with their new single 'Making Love to Morgan Wallen' topping Billboard charts in September 2025. Fred Durst, the band’s frontman, recalls first meeting Rivers at a Jacksonville bar in the early days of the band’s formation, when Rivers’ exceptional bass playing left a lasting impression, cementing his role as a foundational influence on the group’s sound and identity.
title: Sam Rivers, bassist and founding member of Limp Bizkit, dies aged 48
